    • Purpose of the development guidelines

    • LINE offers convenience to users with a range of products, which are built with a combination of the code written by in-house developers, commercial libraries and open source software, running on multiple servers and terminals.
    • Products should be well maintained and consistently improved based on the knowledge of sophisticated technology and runtime environments. Developers of each product should engage in the full spectrum of service process as an owner in order to reinforce the efficiency of such knowledge-based work and maximize product quality including performance, functionality and reliability.
    • However, when such responsibility lies with individuals, it will not only undermine persistence but also make it difficult to prevent mistakes or malicious actions.
    • As such, each product development team should set up their own cooperative structure with at least two persons for cross checking to ensure the quality of code. The roles and responsibilities should also be appropriately distributed between expert teams throughout the development process for cooperation or review in order to prevent mistakes or malicious actions.


    LINE develops various types of services and infrastructure software. We have mandatory policies for each development team to comply with. We separately define respective guidelines for software types and domains as there are differences in development policies, process and practices per software. 

    Mandatory rules for all development projects

    Mandatory rules act as a means of minimum protection for developers against system failures and security incidents and, at the same time, allow them to enjoy discretion during development.

    LINE developers are granted freedom and responsibilities during development but required to comply with the following mandatory rules.

    • At the start of a job

      • Leave commit logs to track code change history and link the job to the corresponding BTS ticket when fulfilling requests
      • Create a BTS ticket after the job in case of an urgent request via messenger 
      • Reference: Project managing with JIRA(BTS) - Android / iOS common (Client JIRA)
    • During coding
      • Peer review is a must for end-user oriented services and platforms and internal tools handling user data. Self-review is prohibited.
    • Security review request
      • As for end-user oriented services and platforms and internal tools handling user data, request AST review to Security Team when the architecture for implementation is confirmed and coding progress reached about 50% of the entire development.
      • The purpose of this security review is to identify potential security vulnerabilities at the code level and prevent risk after the release.
      • Guideline: (1) 開発者向けセキュリティチェック申請ガイド / Security Check Request Guideline
    • At the time of deployment
      • Code should be released through a deployment system that meets the following deployment requirements.
      • Requirements
        • There should be an environment where developers can deploy the code without accessing the server in order to minimize the access to the real server during deployment. 
        • Logs must be kept and managed as audit trail for all code deployment.
      • PMC and nDeploy meet the abovementioned deployment requirements. Any deployment system that fulfills these requirements can be used.
      • Reference: Deployment guideline reference
    • Data access of service logs 
      • To respond to issues without accessing the real server, service logs should be accumulated as IU and used for log analysis.
      • Error logs must be reviewed through the monitoring system.
      • Guideline 
        • Facilities - IMON (Monitoring)
        • Guidelines for the management and archiving of audit logs (Log management/archiving)

    Mandatory rules in detail

    • LINE Product is defined as a single service for general users or internal users. Each product operates on one or more software.
    • Software that composes a LINE Product can be distinguished as backend software that runs on the IDC server, directly operated and managed by LINE, and client software that runs on the user device.
      • Backend software
        • In principle, it is assumed to run on LINE's data center and infrastructure, which means an appropriate level of private network and OS security are provided.
        • Select an optimal technology such as Java, Perl and Python that can deliver on application development requirements. Use the runtime environment version that completed security check.
        • Operating environments of backend software are alpha/beta environment for development and functional tests, staging environment to conduct an integrated test in an environment as close as real service environment and real environment for service. In order to ensure software integrity, the same software is deployed to each environment with different configurations for the respective environments.
        • Web frontend software is, in its nature, a client software as it is loaded into the web browser for execution. However, the execution and update of web frontend software follow the same life cycle as backend software so they are treated the same.
      • Client software
        • Client software is a software developed to run on the user's device with either iOS or Android platform.
        • Client software is deployed through a standard release method defined by each platform, namely App Store or Android Play Store.

Access control on development and service operation servers

     Server access is allowed only when developers need to investigate system or server failures.

(4) Limit direct server access by system operators to handling hardware issues.

Decision making framework at LINE

This page explains the decision making framework of LINE Corporation and LINE Plus Corporation for outsourcing development projects to their overseas development organizations. 

  • At LINE Corporation and LINE Plus Corporation, the Senior Development Leaders Conference (hereinafter "Conference A") allocates jobs, shares issues and makes a final decision.
  • Those senior leaders at LINE and LINE Plus who are responsible for overseas organizations assign key tasks to development leaders at overseas organization, and they report development progress to the Conference A. 
  • Development leaders at each overseas entity are primarily responsible for local development issues in Taiwan, Thailand and Indonesia. And, they share major changes or issues with the CTO and Conference A. When a local entity needs support from resources in another country, the senior leader responsible for the local entity raises an issue with the Conference A for discussion and decision-making. 
    • LINE DEV MGR Home
  • As Monthly Tech Senior Meetings, senior development leaders at each overseas entity share and discuss on-going and future projects.
    • Tech Lead Monthly MTG

Network segments and policies

LINE's network is distinguished into the production network for production and the dev network for development.

In addition, those services* that require network segregation should run on the private zone, which is an infrastructure zone, segregated from the production network with a separate access method.

* Services such as LINE Health Care or LINE Pay

Network segmentPurpose
Dev
  • Development and test environment
Production
  • Overall production services by LINE
Private Zone
  • Services that require network segregation from production
  • Services that should comply with specific laws, regulations or guidelines and the production environment cannot fulfill such requirements

Network ACL

Each network segment has the corresponding network ACL defined under the ACL Guide (LINE Corp ACL Guide). Consequently, it should configure services within these boundaries.

If it requires to communicate via a TCP/UDP which is not covered by the ACL Guide, the security manager must authorize such communication.

In addition, the Private Zone can be segmented further and the security manager must authorize the respective network ACLs for each segment in the private zone.

Accessing production environment from LINER's terminals

Direct access from LINER's terminals to a server in the respective environments is prohibited, and it must always go through a gateway server.

As for servers in the Private Zone, access is allowed via VPN and gateway server for each service. By default, it requires 2-factor authentication for server access.

Each service has their own rules on accessing the Private Zone. Refer to Infra Access Guideline for Private Zone services for more information.

For your information, access to the Private zone is allowed for the relevant project members only. Contact ITSC System Team (#help_infra) for any inquiries.

Security governance

LINE's CISO and CPO is in overall charge of LINE Group security.

LINE requires its employees to comply with the Personal Information Protection Policy and become knowledgeable about the Security Guideline. LINE Group holds regular security training sessions for its employees.

Access permissions

Access permission management system is in place to control access permissions to servers and databases. All activities are retained as audit trail.

Server access

Each server manages access control with IDMS.

Permissions for developers should be authorized by the head of an organization. Permission to access LINE messaging service requires an approval by the security manager.

Server access is allowed only through the gateway server, and all command history is recorded.

Refer to the Infra Service Access Guide for more information.

Database access

As for database, access permissions are managed per instance with DBIP.

Permissions for developers should be authorized by the head of an organization and database manager.

Access to MySQL database is allowed only through the SQL Gateway. All SQL queries are recorded.

Refer to the Guide for requesting database related work for more information.

Tool access

As for those internal tools that handle personal information, access permissions must be controlled with IIMS to allow only authorized users to access.

Achieve the following goals with IIMS:

  • Access control through SSO authentication
  • Permission management in line with work scope
  • Authorization history management
  • Tool access history management

This document has been reorganized into Development Process Regulations and LINE Development Process Guidelines. 

Please refer to Development Process Regulations for the latest development regulations. 

This document gives an overview of governance for product development at LINE. 

1. Organization structure for development and operation

The following organizations develop and operate all products offered by LINE.

1.1 Regional structure

Find the following reference for the corporate structure of LINE.

  • Regional structure

1.2 Governance structure

LINE development organizations are located in seven countries, and they engage in development under the framework of development governance of LINE Group.

LINE Corporation is responsible to set up the structure to oversee and manage the governance of the entire LINE Group.

Primary governance responsibility lies with the developer leader of each development organization and LINE Group's CTO is finally in charge of overall governance of LINE Group.

Refer to the overall governance framework of the development organizations at LINE.

Find the following reference for the decision making process and development control at LINE Group.

  • Development control at LINE

1.3 Non-stop (24x365) monitoring for systems and services 

  • System monitoring 

    • Operators stationed at the IDC are responsible for 24 x 7 monitoring and primary handling of alerts.

    • Operators conduct system monitoring with the error management system. In case of a system failure, alerts are sent to respective development teams based on application alerts registered in the IOC (Infra Operation Center, https://ioc.linecorp.com).

  • Service monitoring

    • TTS (Trouble Ticket System) Team at LINE Fukuoka Corporation conducts the following service monitoring tasks.

      • Discuss about the route of service distribution and monitoring methodology

      • Conduct service monitoring for 24 hours and 365 days
      • Send the system error report to relevant teams in case of an issue
      • How to register at TTS and request monitoring: About monitoring and fault management of Service

2. LINE development culture

LINE pursues to build a development culture for engineers to be autonomous, to be open and cooperative based on trust and respect, to take challenges and make contributions and to take ownership of their own projects and conduct peer reviews. LINE also aims to grow engineers with such cultural DNA. 

  • Engineering Culture at LINE

3. Process and regulations for product development

LINE employees are required to comply with the fundamental governance framework in order to maintain the autonomous development culture. Find the following regulations and guidelines for compliance.

3.1 Technical regulations

At LINE, 'Regulations for service development management' is at the top of the hierarchy of service development governance. 'Development process regulations', 'QA activity guidelines' and 'Service release guidelines' also make a part of this governance. Developers must comply with the following regulations and guidelines during development. 

3.1.1 Regulations for service development management

Follow the link below for the Regulations for service development management.

  • F10 Regulations for service development management - No. 20210228

3.1.2 Development process regulations

LINE develops a wide range of services and infrastructure software. We have mandatory policies for each development team to comply with. We separately define respective guidelines for software types and domains as there are differences in development policies, process and practices per software. Find the following common regulations regardless of types or domains.

  • Development Process Regulations

3.1.3 QA activity guidelines

LINE conducts QA (quality assurance) activities to reinforce the quality of services developed by LINE. QA activities at each development stage are defined in the following guideline. 

  • QA Activity Guidelines in the Project Lifecycle

3.1.4 Service release guidelines

At LINE, we comply with the following service release guidelines and use the checklist to confirm completion. Comply with the following termination guideline when terminating a service.

  • (Replaced) LINE Service Release Guide
  • Service Sunset Guide

3.2 Security and data regulations

We have regulations for information security and data under the development process governance as follows.

3.2.1 Regulations for information security

  • Security Guideline
    • 情報セキュリティポリシー (Information security policy)
    • Personal Information Protection Management Policy
    • Information security related policies

3.2.2 Regulations for data

  • Confidentiality Level Classification Guide (Data handling)

4. Infrastructure for production environment and data storage

4.1 IDC (Internet Data Center)

Refer to this IDC guideline on IDC environments for each service infrastructure environment and purpose.

4.2 Production environment

Infrastructure for LINE services is designed on Verda, a private cloud platform at LINE, with the company-wide infrastructure controls.

It requires authentication and approval by the infrastructure and security admin to use the private cloud platform and audit trail must be maintained for any activities on the cloud platform.

Refer to the documentation on Verda environments for more information. 

5. Network

LINE's network is distinguished into the production network for production and the dev network for development.

In addition, those services that require network segregation should run on the private zone, segregated from the production network.

Refer to Network governance for more information on services with network segregation, policy on access to the private zone and ACL guide on the network boundary.

6. Security

6.1 Security governance

LINE's CISO and CPO is in overall charge of LINE Group security.

Refer to Security governance for more information on security management framework at LINE. 

6.2 Access permissions

Access permissions to servers, databases and tools are managed by the Permission Management System. History of all actions on these systems must be retained as audit trail. Refer to Security governance for more information. 

7. Code management

At LINE Group, the source code is managed on the GitHub Enterprise and it must be saved in one of the following instances. Refer to Facilities - GitHub for more information.

  • https://git.linecorp.com
    • Instance for LINE Group employees or interns
    • Plan to redefine rules and configurations to allow outsourcing staff to access in the future
  • https://git-dev.linecorp.com
    • Instance for LINE Group employees, third-party employees or outsourcing staff for cooperation
    • This instance will be closed when https://git.linecorp.com is open to third-party employees or outsourcing staff.
  • https://github.com/line
    • Instance for public disclosure of OSS (Open Source Software) by LINE
